t: Proverbs 5
Pitfalls of Immorality
My*pn son, give attention to my wisdom, Incline*ln your ear to my understanding;
That*ln you may observe discretion And*ln your lips may reserve knowledge.
For*ln the lips of an adulteress drip honey And*ln smoother than oil is her speech;
But*ln in the end she is bitter as wormwood, Sharp*ln as a two-edged sword.
Her*ln feet go down to death, Her*ln steps take hold of Sheol.
She*ln does not ponder the path of life; Her*ln ways are unstable, she does not know it.*i
Now*ln then, my*i sons, listen to me And*ln do not depart from the words of my mouth.
Keep*ln your way far from her And*ln do not go near the door of her house,
Or*ln you will give your vigor to others And*ln your years to the cruel one;
And*ln strangers will be filled with your strength And*ln your hard-earned goods will*i go*i to the house of an alien;
And*ln you groan at your final end, When*ln your flesh and your body are consumed;
And*ln you say, “How I have hated instruction! And*ln my heart spurned reproof!
I*ln have not listened to the voice of my teachers, Nor*ln inclined my ear to my instructors!
I*ln was almost in utter ruin In*ln the midst of the assembly and congregation.”
Drink*ln water from your own cistern And*ln fresh water from your own well.
Should*ln your springs be dispersed abroad, Streams*ln of water in the streets?
Let*ln them be yours alone And*ln not for strangers with you.
Let*ln your fountain be blessed, And*ln rejoice in the wife of your youth.
As*iln a loving hind and a graceful doe, Let*ln her breasts satisfy you at all times; Be*ln exhilarated always with her love.
For*ln why should you, my son, be exhilarated with an adulteress And*ln embrace the bosom of a foreigner?
For*ln the ways of a man are before the eyes of the Lord,*s And*ln He watches all his paths.
His*ln own iniquities will capture the wicked, And*ln he will be held with the cords of his sin.
He*ln will die for lack of instruction, And*ln in the greatness of his folly he will go astray.
